tscQwsq8UlmCdN-ekJrOjg.text: Yum! I had the Figs and Blue Cheese with Prosciutto for my app and the Gnocchi with sun-dried tomatoes for my main entree with a tasty little creme brulee for dessert. I must say over all, delicious. My 4 star rating comes from the service. We sat downstairs and as another review stated, we felt a little forgotten about. We were there to have a nice relaxing dinner, but by the time we were ready for the check we waited almost 30 minutes and then started to hunt for our server upstairs!

7Idv2uOkXSr8F5a2TK_NwQ.text: A block from Tottenham Court station. Their slogan is "Affordable gourmet food," and it's true. I had a carafe of tempranillo, fig and goat cheese starter, authentic beef bourgignon, espresso and chocolate mousse. £33 isn't cheap, but for that meal is affordable, because it all *was* gourmet. The decor is fun and colorful, the waitresses friendly and authentically French. It's possible to spend less there, for less dinner: the tempranillo was £11 of my total. But the mousse was especially good. :)

okJBflbOEkjLioX6_Ypzng.text: We ate here before the theater. This is a nice but simple  place with good food and good service.  I would certainly return.

OQnTo5w5HRuUb67kyiMbNA.text: No disappointments here, as always, absolutely remarkable cuisine and ambiance. The staff bend over backwards to make sure your meals are most satisfactory and they don't skimp on portions either.A wonderful place to take guests or just to enjoy a bottle of wine and escargot!

EA03Dg6b8Lh7-iexaDJzeA.text: Amazing food, huge portions, dirt cheap prices. My new London fav.

byJKOtjDM6gVC5_fa9l9Sw.text: I have eaten at Savoir Faire on and off for many years and when I am in London this is always worth a stop. Visitors I have brought here have never been disappointed. I favor the baked escargot, duck and the house red wine. Enjoy!

-qAzODk2lfUEdc_CDdHXkw.text: I struggle to give this place a five, but it is solid and one of the few places in London where you get a lot for your money.  We were seated at the front of the restaurant, and every time someone walked through the door, you would hear a dinging noise go off.  A bit annoying.  The atmosphere is great and the waitresses were very nice and always smiling--what a treat.  The food was good , but nothing mind-blowing or spectacular.  It was an enjoyable meal, but nothing I am rushing to go back for.

XjGX5j_N5T_f_8YoSfcBJQ.text: very nice little place. I had the rib eye steak which was delicious. My friend's lamb shank was nice too. We shared a goose rillette (nice as well) and a coffee brûlée which was amazing.

dm75rVyty2JH0QA2-0NDRA.text: Interesting place. It's a great deal, particularly considering the location. The food's average-to-good, but definitely nothing to write home about - classic bistro cooking, the flaws being e.g. too tough beef bourguignon, lack of flavour in a couple of the dishes. However, a few things let it down. First, the service, while friendly, is slow and inattentive (whenever we needed one of the waiting staff, there was no-one to be seen and I spent more time than I liked trying to catch their eye). Second, the decor is basic but a few things need some touching up, and e.g. the cutlery/glassware look very much like they belong in a school canteen. Third, the wine selection is very ordinary, which is shame for a French restaurant - we had one of the more expensive bottles and, while inoffensive, it wasnt very interesting. I'll definitely bear it in mind for the future, but you won't find me going out of my way to come back, and especially not with a date or someone I'm trying to impress. There are much better restaurants in this kind of category (Comptoir Gascon instantly springs to mind, as does Le Mercury).

JyOotnwBlSKGdcLez8nrpQ.text: Whenever I'm in London this is always my first choice place to go to eat. It used to be a Pierre-Victiore and has kept the cheap bistro fixed price menu ethos. At two courses for £10 the menu provides great value and often contains some exciting ingrdients such as duck breast or sucking pig. The staff are casual but attentive and friendly. It is often busy has a vibrant atmosphere.Another plus point of the restaurant is the way that they respond to a problem. We had an awful meal there (on one of our 30 odd visits) and they could not do enough to put it right. Without wanting to sound too sentimental this restaurante has been part of some great memories for me and everyone should give it a go. Some of the best value food in London.

_KHe3hkj_xLP2rgL3O9d7g.text: Just came back from dinner at Savior Faire, and I am still thinking about the food we enjoyed so much. For starter, I had fried goat cheese with caramelized pears. My main entree was duck with caramelized oranges, carrots, and zucchini, and potato gratin. The food melt in my mouth. The flavor was scrumptious!! I would recommend that place to anyone who visits London. Our experience at that restaurant was very positive.

ErMnE7VGaiW6VOhFXwQp1w.text: Loved the authentic French cuisine and the price was reasonable too.  Can't beat that!

AURk8f5J1aqzVK5DQsexYg.text: Well, it was our last night in London and we were looking for a suitable restaurant.  Being the Yelper that I am, I set about with researching.  We have some picky eaters in our group, so that added another element of difficulty.  As a bunch of Francophiles, I thought a French restaurant would be a good choice.  Based on the preceeding Yelp reviews, we finally settled on Savoir Faire.  I was intrigued by the basement grotto, so when I made the reservation on Open Table, I requested that we be seated down there.  This was good because we got a bit raucous and silly as the meal progressed.  Well, we were not disappointed by Savoir Faire in the least. We all ordered the two course, prix fixe menu.  I began with the roasted figs accompanied by stilton and prosciutto.  They were just lovely!  Then I tucked into the magret de carnard, but I felt that the duck was a bit over-cooked (Erin agreed).  I also had a nibble of Maeve's beef bourguignon.  Delicious!  The gnocchi that Courtney had was a bit odd looking, but she said it was good.  Chris and Miguel both had the Creole chicken and they cleaned their plates.  We also had about 5 bottles of some white wine (Chardonnay, I believe).  For desert we ordered a couple creme-brulees, the banoffee pie (my favorite!), and a very sad chocolate mousse (more like a pudding cup).  The wait-staff was nice, but we often felt a bit neglected at times. I guess that's what you get for hiding away in a cave.  The murals on the walls also provided some amusement for our group and some of them were pretty risque! Overall, a tres bon experience!

mPX-liOAXzl2B3dcDSeCbQ.text: I stumbled across this place about 10 years ago and have been regularly returning. Very well prepared French dishes at remarkably reasonable prices. My favorite has always been the Duck Magret with on sauteedd Leeks and Potato with Orange and Balsamic Sauce. Always nicely done. If you're heading to Shaftsbury theatres they have wonderful pre-theatre specials and will see to it that you are out in time for the show.

fXpr7SEbgbr2K3V8w54eXQ.text: What can I say that hasn't been said?  This place is absolutely charming.  It manages a balance between a cozy cafe and a more sophisticated feel.  The painted murals on the walls make the small room seem larger and friendly.  We came in for a very late lunch and the owner (we presume) greeted us immediately, made a very good wine suggestion and defeated every stereotype of snooty French right away.  Our waitress was a bit cold, to be honest, and seemed irritated with us when she brought us the wrong wine...but really she wasn't RUDE, just not the smiley sort that another Yelper had mentioned.  We had steak with chips and salad...simple food that didn't seem entirely French in my mind, but was prepared so beautifully that I can't wait to go back.  Excellent value for money!

U8Hs9sidmE_AeutOXkT0tA.text: Excellent French food, friendly and efficient service, nice atmosphere without being large or noisy, great all-around experience

dNVyDFUtiCQ8omEMQvXToA.text: Good meat, nicely sized portions, sauvignon blanc priced well and tasted better than vinegar.  Made a reservation on open table and they treated me very well

QWcW2fCnsHmwfSndCVo9cw.text: A traditional French bistro which does an excellent set pre or post theatre dinner. Try and get a seat downstairs if you can. Excellent set menu which represents good value for money and choices change on a regular basis. The staff are attentive and its always pretty full which is always a recommendation. This is the sort of place to take your mum when she comes to visit or a date for a low key dinner. The desserts are a definite highlight especially the banoffee pie.

MpVO_TiumyPSZwPUfGuuSA.text: Wonderful, wonderful French food and a wonderful atmosphere. Great place for a leisurely romantic dinner. Highly recommended!

vhVLI8geGXlOREpFlYVHRw.text: Loved it.  Thought the food was completely reasonably priced for the quality of the meal!  Also, was nice to have a break from fried food or Italian.  It was a comfortable place to eat, and was in high demand.  Make a reservation!!

b6__J-MqfA_Tgxkd_p7e_w.text: After reading all the great reviews about this restaurant we decided to give it a go recently. Overall an ok experience, but nothing really that stood out, hence we probably won't be going back.So to the details... As we arrived we were seated downstairs and the whole area smells of a cellar or a damp basement, which isn't very pleasant but you quickly get used to it. One of the reviewers mentioned images of 'naked ladies' plastering the walls, which we've seen none of - a bit disappointing:)The service was very friendly and attentive, but the food took forever to arrive, so make sure that you allocate plenty of time if you decide to visit. We ordered a french wine (unfortunately I don't remember the name of it), which was recommended as 'owners favourite' and it was in fact quite nice and affordable.The dishes are quite big, so even the most demanding stomachs shouldn't be left disappointed, while those with smaller tummies make sure to NOT eat the bread that's brought in at the start, I know it's fresh, with a crunchy crust and tasty, but otherwise you won't be able to finish your dishes:) I had lamb following recommendations of numerous reviewers and my wife had duck. Both dishes were quite nice, but they were very much like home-cooked food I haven't felt anything exquisite about them.So to sum up, the service is great, food takes a while to arrive, the dishes are more like home-cooked rather than French exquisite cuisine.

o8WB5us9rDWUTGSk_MiG0g.text: Was looking for somewhere near the British Museum to get an early dinner, and came here because it had so many good reviews on Yelp. Thanks, Yelp.The prices are very reasonable for central London and the food was great, with generous portions (I went for the mussels and then the steak, two courses for £21). Add what turned out to be a very nice bottle of wine for £20 and it was about £70 for the two of us. We ended up staying much longer than planned, and never got the feeling we were being chivvied out of the place. I'd definitely go back here if I was in town, and I'd recommend it to others too.

2Fkus13sPnvE0NTnt2StTw.text: Yelpers. you did not steer me wrong!! Honestly, I am so happy with this place and this is coming from someone who normally isnt a huge fan of french food.  a) Service:  We came in on a Saturday night with no reservations and were greeted with a friendly smile by a lovely lady.  She sat us within 5 minutes and actually moved our seats around to make us more comfortable.b) Environment: This place is super cute without being pretentious with smaller tables, which I like so you can actually have a good private conversation. c) Food: Exceptional.  You can find as healthy or unhealthy food as you want, with lighter food options ranging from salads and bouillabaise (which incidentally I ordered), to proper  two and three course meals. I know it silly, but we actually  had warm crusty bread, which is one of my favorite things, and they DIDNT charge us -- SHOCKING!!  My husband had the baked goat cheese and tapenade and steak as a main.  My friend had the goose rillette with duck magret.  Everyone gobbled down their meals happily.  We had a carafe of the house red and followed by courvoisier and creme brulee, which I have to say delicious. d) Value:  All of the above was around 90 pounds. What a great deal for a VERY expensive city :)  I will absolutely be here again with a delicious gourmet meal with beautiful presentation without the price tag.

UvqgcrbBJO9QSGOE65VEiA.text: Wonderful lunch after a visit to the British Museum.  Reasonable prices and delicious. Very kind people and accommodating to my children. Eat here!

e25ZzCCps0W0nWXFg_nzLA.text: We were in London for  week and staying in a hotel near the British museum. There were not a lot of choices for dinner within walking distance so we searched YELP for help and found this one. It was just down the street from the museum so we called to book a table and they had one for us.. We strolled over and were promptly seated at a charming table by the window. It was a relaxing atmosphere and the owners were wonderful hosts making sure we were well taken care of. I had the pork belly for dinner and it was beautifully crisp on the outside and succulent on the inside. Yum! The best meal during our stay.

0KtqRuO60g5B7btBM_VWHw.text: We had lunch here after a visit to the British Museum.  We are foodies who have visited Paris, and the fare here is delicious.  We enjoyed the Roast Beef and Brie sandwich, the roasted Chicken with Avocado and Tarragon Aioli sandwich, and the Chicken Caesar Salad.  All three were delicious, as was our Crème Brulee and Mousse au Chocolat for dessert.  House white wine was quite good.  Prices were very reasonable for a London restaurant.  Highly recommended.

3nizRXkok5pmlLM0DK4JPw.text: OK, but I really didn't understand the 5 star reviews for this place. Oddly decorated, slow service and very English French food... Meh

v8gj4SnXItJgUFLZL5aKxw.text: Two thing I remember was their lamb and mussel served in escargot pan.They were so good.The service was good. Food was good and not pricy.Service was fast.Bread they served was yummy.Overall it was great experience and I am so glad I picked this place.If I ever go back to London, yes I want to go back:)

VHVk2yhK06DDBvtlJsCyhA.text: Located in the heart of London's theatre district, Savoir Faire stands out for its warm and friendly atmosphere. A nice change from the abundance of large chains in London. The quirky decor is charming. I especially liked the ceiling. The food is delicious, and you can't complain about the portions. They are huge! The lamb shank was succulent with a delicious sauce, while my partner loved the rillette starter. I would recommend you go.

jMq1ZJDu01TPsTneV8q__g.text: French dining at its best.  The ambiance is casual and laid back, the food is fantastic and the service is great.  This is a must visit and easy to get to (especially after a visit to the British museum) I had one of the beef plates which was delicious. Their set menu is excellent value. The only thing is that it can feel a bit crowded and then around 9 ish the downstairs can get empty and you feel like it is midnight, so try to get a table upstairs.

dBuMxFUEb1sOvGJ6ISPg4g.text: The food tasted homemade and delishous. We sat by the window which was nice - you could watch the street and the people outside. For me the atmosphere was quite right - this place is 20 years old and has been in private hands - a good sign with so many chains and cooperations popping up in this neighbourhood. Service was very friendly and good. I can totally recommend this place and would go back - maybe even will on my next visit in London.

HYTJAJtOpZ1O1SOA6RpNZg.text: Very nice and cost atmosphere with very good service. Had the lamb and it was very good. A place I will go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

NUW9RU9Cx2GqcXJLMjtFcw.text: Service was welcoming, helpful and prompt. As they suggest on their website, their emphasis is on value and quality. This is honest cooking from honest ingredients and served well, and it is not a fancy place. I mean to compliment them by saying their food was like "grandma's good Sunday cooking". We each had goose rilletes, then Burgundian beef stew and lamb shank both with creamy mashed potatoes, carrots and broccoli. The wine we selected was adequate, and priced well. The ambience is humble but clean and quiet enough to converse. Overall very satisfied.

0klMmoHBWzMhRe4UPY3daw.text: Came here for lunch after the day spent at the British Museum. The food is SPECTACULAR.  The service attentive without being hurried. The wait staff gladly made recommendations for wine that suited a variety of tastes.  The meal...from starter to coffee for dessert was spectacular!  I had the bouillabaisse and my daughter had the lamb shank.  We had goat cheese starter and split a bottle of the French pinot noir.  Will definitely try and return during our stay in London.

JPNeVuWoL5zQ8NKth-oyHw.text: We just finished a dinner at Savoir Faire and had a great time! It's tiny,completely authentic and the food is well cooked. We had the beef bourguignon which was amazing. Rosted bell peper soup was interesting but wouldn't order it again. Small place and super cozy for a wintery evening.

Qzr-q9uv8QEGpeyykMI4fw.text: If you're lookingfor a better restaurant with the same pricing but better customer service andfood come to Savoir Faire, hopefully you are fortunate and have a betterexperience and itis all worth visiting. Theambiance is nice and you should come if you like looking adifferent Frenchplaces.The prices here are very reasonable and the food was great! The food isalways top of the lineand in affordable prices.

1TpS1lk--htJDefynd8YQQ.text: We ended up stopping in here compliments of the Yelp app, which seldom steers us wrong. I'm glad we listened. It was affordable and delicious and the atmosphere was adorable. We felt comfortable just hanging out for a long while and enjoying a leisurely Sunday meal with friends. I had high hopes for the fried goat's cheese. It was good, but I'd give it a pass next time. Also, two people at the table ordered ceasar salads and said they tasted oddly salty. Other than those complaints, everything at the table got rave reviews from starters to mains and desserts. And the wine! Delicious. For location, good food, and price point, it's definitely a gem that we'd go back to anytime.

CnNLVaQFW1PcHCU6bBkx8g.text: This place sits on the corner of a narrow but busy London three-street intersection. If you possibly can, get a seat on the street level floor in front of the picture window that looks out on that intersection, which it seems like all of London crosses thru.. It's like sitting in front of a wall-high diorama, one that always changes, with big red double-deckers rumbling thru one second, then taxi-cabs in the opposite direction the next, then more vehicles coming at you from the street opposite your corner and curving away the next, and then these bicyclist commuters pumping fearlessly away alongside these guys in this very narrow space.. and then pedestrians scurrying past you on the sidewalk..Hey Yelp.. you led us right! Based on Yelp reviews, we dropped in here after exhausting ourselves with an afternoon in the British Museum. Like what everyone else says, it was a treat.. the *best* meal we had during our vacation (but.. well.. not that much competition really.. people are not kidding when they complain about British cuisine), reasonable prices (because we dropped in early, around 6 they gave us a special, lower-priced "Pre-show" menu, I guess with smaller portions and one course options that suited us just fine). Enjoyed our meal and wine and just sitting in front of that damn fine window looking at the world come and go so much we ended up ordering dessert and coffee.. just to stay a little longer.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. lingering over dessert

jGRZ_I5HFkWfNTBCvEe87w.text: Felt like a bit of Paris dropped in the middle of London. We were looking for an authentic French meal and found it at Savoir Faire. The service was excellent, food selection to our liking. The prices were reasonable and we were able to get a reservation quickly.  The house wine went well with the meal. I will return to this restaurant during my next visit to London.

wCrCTBSUux3tuHenp73j1Q.text: Outstanding!  We both had steak and fries with salad and half a bottle of the house red, all of which was delicious.  The cheesecake and crème brulee for dessert were both excellent. the service was impeccable throughout and the whole meal was very good value for money indeed.  I can't rate it too highly.  We'll definitely be back!

xk7hcsIeAPWd9Kt4XfZliw.text: Came across this very nice and cozy place. We made a reservation for dinner. It was sooooooo worth it.First- The service was very nice and helpful. The food came quick even though there were a lot of people. Second- The most important part... the food!! It was excellent. Its French cousine. I got the ceasar salad. It didnt have the ceasar dressing but they had something better, balsamic vinegar dressing. It was delicious. My mom got the escargot. She said it was good.  For the main course, i got the beef burger with a mini-salad and fries as a side dish. The patty was cooked to perfection and the fries were not greasy at all.We also got the cheesecake, and it was good.  Overall, I would come back.

VdHofPPyvHpf0zvKloGfww.text: Heaven by way of mussels and lamb shanks. I just stumbled upon this place thanks to yelp. Cozy French casual restaurant in Bloomsbury. Good value for gourmet food and the staff 's really attentive and nice. I will come back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Crime brulee
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Lambshank hefty serving!!
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Mussels yum

_PJqLLNwtkidePcuG4Th8w.text: Really good Rillettes, Foie Gras, duck, rib eye, Creme brûlée

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Rillettes
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Foie gras
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

VY31QUNg0f6i3iOswgypmA.text: Went for dinner before a show. Surprisingly, there was plenty of availability on a Friday night. The staff was friendly, the 50's French music added to the ambiance, but the food was only slightly above average and the service took a bit too long given our theater time constraints. The best part, though, was the reasonably priced meal.

NXNF89lgxlT2osnwxCDh_Q.text: I thought i'd walked into the wrong restaurant.  Be warned this place is not classy or refined ...its rustic to put it nicely. Further perhaps because it was 5:30pm Tuesday, the place was empty except for 5 senior couples.  This part i didn't mind but a 6th old couple walked in and decided that from the 10 empty tables they wanted to sit next to us ...and then proceeded to stare and eavesdrop for the next 30mts whilst we rapidly finished our meal.Anyway to backtrack a little, when we sat down were were given 4 menus including the price fix menu, pre-theater menu, al la carte menu and drinks menu.   After consulting yelp and foursquare i decided on the goats cheese and the lambshank and the wife got the sea bass.  The food was excellent and made up for the above shortcomings.  The prices were very good given we were just outside convent garden tourist-ville.  We will definitely go back...but maybe after 7pm next time to try a different vibe!

CsJrw1zoZaIjC8OfjbSpXw.text: Bijoux is the best way to describe this gem serving hearty food in cozy, slightly eccentric decor. It almost seems a bit out of place on the bustling New Oxford Street, yet step inside and you are miles away from the the noise and chaos of the city. This Bloomsbury neighbourhood favourite is a bit a France in the heart of the city. The traditional French bistro menu is simple food cooked very well. And at very reasonable prices! As the locals seem to know. Our mid week supper felt like a feast here.

_JC_uL5sCBXDU0dqL_u0cQ.text: First things first: the food is glorious. It's also reasonably priced, especially considering the quality. I had my dinner outside, so I could watch the passersby and enjoy a cigar. The interaction was almost as good as the meal. I was asked for directions and change. Thank goodness the server was well versed in local geography and blessed with patience, as I was essentially useless for all queries, save those regarding my cigar. I was scolded by - I think - a Cuban expatriate for smoking Castro's cigars. Just for the record, it's Honduran. The half-carafe of  house wine is better than passable, but not exceptional. The service, while relaxed and non-hurried is friendly and enjoyable. I don't post nearly enough recommendations here on Yelp, but here ya go: I recommend Savoir Faire. Oh, and the free wifi is nice. It is, in fact part of the reason you are reading these bon mots. Bon appetite!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Appetizer of feta cheesecake.
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Dinner

bQjd-CQRihWPNZfcZxgJ4Q.text: Great food and drinks at a reasonable price. Service was a bit slow, but other than that would highly recommend!

CkT31pNvSCsF9jOyiALoTA.text: My mother and grandmother were visiting London and I was tasked with finding a place near them for a nice meal on a Friday evening. I am pleased to say that Savoir Faire ticked all the boxes we needed for this situation: we needed decent food but not too expensive, with a decent atmosphere but not too loud, walking distance from Russell square, and able to take booking at short notice. We tried a few Italian places near by, but they were not picking up the phone. Their loss, as Savoir Faire allowed us to book online with very little notice; and all four members of our party enjoyed ourselves.The menus were printed on a couple of sheets of A4, in about as slapdash a fashion as you could muster, and then stapled together. But that didn't detract from the selection of great sounding French dishes. The selection was a little modest, but it did have a "light menu" of smaller plates and salads. Ideal for the varied crowd at our table.From the photos I expected quite small but beautifully executed gourmet French dishes, but in actuality it was more classic cooking at affordable prices. That is no bad thing: I cannot resist a beef bourguignon and this one did not disappoint. Flavoursome beef just melted in the mouth alongside creamy mash and rich sauce. Even the most basic of seasonal vegetables; carrots and broccoli, were lovely. Everyone else seemed very pleased with their lamb shank, chicken salad, and duck breast.The service was great too; numerous waitresses were very attentive, swift with drinks, and then left us to chatter long after our last course was finished. The freedom to relax and finish drinks after a meal is a real plus on any venue, I absolutely detest being hurried out of the door or hassled for the bill.The menu as I mentioned was a little on the small side from what I'd expect, but it was by no means bad, and everything we ordered food-wise was excellent. The only real complaint I could give was that the Irish coffee I had afterwards was pretty foul - but I'm not going to get on the back of French restaurant too much for this mistake.If you like classic French dishes, a good atmosphere in a relatively small place, and a good bite to eat at short notice, you should definitely pop in here.

4Quk4ddS0Jf62sQeAjs24Q.text: The food was good, but the service was really slow. There were two reasons for this, it was only the second day of one of the servers, and we were one of the two couples that were downstairs, and I think it was a little of out of site, out of mind.

rwLpD4batGV9tfkkImdBgw.text: I wouldn't go as far as calling it French, but a interesting menu none the less. The menu is printed on a single piece of paper and therefore limited. This was my first time here, but I'm thinking they change it often. Regardless I like small menu's, because - as we proved again this evening - it normally means everything is freshly madeEverything we ordered was fantastic and not to expensive either. You can get away with a 2 course meal for £20

ZBYEJrp7J1Knq6UyzGNeCA.text: Well when the kids like the foie gras you know you're off to a great start!  Excellent meal--we had the sea bass, steak, chicken and mussels and everyone thought it was yummy. Our server even helped avoid a meltdown from our youngest with a quick discussion about drink choices. Well done!I would highly recommend this place.

rEnQDBUYdXgJ5FjpTYn4_Q.text: We enjoyed our dinners between the Caesar salad and French onion soup.  Then we had salmon and beef bourginon that were excellent.   Service was excellent   They gave us time between courses.  We would highly recommend this restaurant.  We came without a reservation and they were very accommodating on a Saturday night

p0zNLRKQflqfkvOxpnXD2g.text: I've just eaten a fantastic traditional beef bourguignon in this restaurant... It was server with vegetables and "purée". Reallly good! I'll come back here asap!

07DdCd5tZVCbkaDBNvK2Fw.text: This review covers two different visits:1- After our exhausting British museum visit one afternoon, my friend and I stumbled upon this tiny restaurant and recalling that it had been packed the previous night we figured it would be a good place for a much needed dose of caffeine and sweets.  At the time we were the only customers there.  Turns out they have the best latte and Banoffee pie in town, and with a French name you'd expect nothing less- except when we got their business card we noticed that the owner is actually Persian!  Classic switcheroo!  Service was also good (by one of the owners I believe).  There we rested like weary travelers of the days of yore, connected to their free wi-fi, snapped a pic or two, and eventually headed out, highly satisfied with our experience.   4 stars2- We returned a few days later, in the evening this time- hoping that the delicious offering on our previous visit was a prelude to amazing things to come on the dinner front.  We made a reservation and when we showed up the place was packed, which we took as a good sign, but there was an eerie tension in the air - most customers either looked irritated or were actually complaining about something - it looked as if many had been waiting for a really long time for their food to arrive.  This time, our waitress had a bit of an attitude problem, which for a small family run restaurant was a little unusual, but luckily wine came to our rescue, there was no great delay with our food and when it did arrive, while not mind-blowing, was above average.  The place definitely has an 'intimate' setting, not necessarily in the romantic sense- well perhaps that too- but it definitely feels cramped when busy, so be prepared to get fairly up close and personal with your neighbour.  As a result, it doesn't score highly for me on the comfort front.  3 starsp.s.  nowhere is this size inconvenience more... ummm... inconvenient, than the shockingly small bathroom - absolutely horrible- it's midget sized I tell ya!  Avoid a call of nature at all costs - or perhaps try it to fully appreciate my horror!  Overall 3.5 stars but since we can't do halves, I'll round it up to 4.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Banoffee pie

ec7hRfFUbCk0ssQqNOe5dQ.text: Amazing! The baked mussels were incredible, you may need extra bread to soak up all the goodness. The duck with cranberry was cooked perfectly.  The clementine compote was so flavorful and sticky toffee pudding with whiskey creme sauce was the perfect way to end the meal.

OR_RJ9QXXN7GaQ8p8i9RSg.text: This place is great! service is impeccable and the food is made with precision and care. ordered the liver and beef daube and it was excellent. perfectly cooked and presented. also order the creme brule and choclate mousse. All desserts are made fresh daily!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

s43vV8bGypdEElEmn5Po6A.text: Savoir Faire is a great value French restaurant that remains competitive, despite the emergence of superior alternatives elsewhere. I've been here three times now for my work's Christmas lunch over the years (including 2013) and have been happy each time. Savoir Faire's chief strength is its impressive value and quality for the prices charged. Sure, it's been overhauled by Le Mercury on Upper Street, but it's nevertheless much better than most restaurants in its price range. Meat is tender, vegetables well-cooked and desserts satisfying. Service is friendly and accommodating, to the point of allowing us to this year stay a little longer to indulge in some post-lunch quiz action.Here's to Christmas 2014!

7ko0eUxD9tzG-y4bdfDAKA.text: Completely unfancy in setting and presentation, but delicious and lush in taste! The menu is amusing in that it's 2 photocopied papers stapled back-to-back. Odd to say the least. The dishes are offered as a set menu or with a few a la carte offerings.The food was just yummy. The rest of my group had hot dishes, but I went for the unique sounding chicken salad. It was the nicest salad I think I've ever had! So many fresh and well-prepared ingredients and beautifully char-grilled chicken to top. The creme brulee wasn't the best ever, but it was tasty (and I can rarely resist a creme brulee)!  My husband had the beef bourguignon and raved about it. A quirky little place, but one I would be more than happy to visit again!

RC-9LY5Be5hawc2h7ZwiWQ.text: I love Yelp. And I love it even more for directing me to the wonderful and divine Savoir Faire. This restaurant is like a breath of fresh country-air in the centre of a busy, bustling and let's be honest, slightly dirty city. Family owned and family run, this is a great slice of rustic French cuisine. I went here with a group of nine on a Friday night. Our table was ready, our waitress was superb and we were made to feel really welcome. The wine list was a hit with my partner (the aspiring amateur sommelier) and we kicked off the evening with a lovely Riesling from Alsace, called Rifile. This was so good (not too sweet, and perfectly balanced), and I even went to my parents local wine cavern Byrne's of Clitheroe, to find some more bottles of the stuff. Fab. I went for the foie gras - wonderfully rich and perfectly matched with the apple and brioche. For my main I went for the Sea Bass which was again, exquisitely cooked and the tomato and pepper sauce delicate and flavoursome. Between nine of us we hit most of the items on the 2 courses for £16 deal. Bargain. Other highlights included the salmon gateaux and the rich duck dish. Yum. We were so relaxed we even took in some desserts and coffee. My friend even venturing to try some grappa!!!I did also venture into the small private dining area as I was intrigued by the murals. Now, I thought from previous reviews that the murals were hand painted BY Lautrec, now I'm no Art Historian, but they looked pretty new to be around 100 years old. So, I think they're probably a copy and homage at best. Still pretty though!Quite simply, Savoir Faire is great, fab and brilliant all at the same time. A perfect place to chill with friends whilst sampling some top notch French food. This isn't haute cuisine, but all portions are generous, tasty and definitely value for money. I'll be back in a flash, as soon as I persuade some more friends to go, judging by their emails the next day about how fab the food was, I don't think it will be long.

vwxsw0Pzlr8DUlb3J7Ejwg.text: This is a special place to take your loved one for a romantic meal. The restaurant is a family run business and you can tell by the care that is put into both service and food. The decor is also lovely with an ambiance that makes me feel within the renaissance era. The food is fantastic and quite authentically French. What is surprising is the price. For what is one of the better dining experiences in London, this restaurant is very affordable. At under £20 for a main meal this is excellent value.I hear there are secret tunnels within the restaurant that you can dine in for a really exclusive feel. I will be back again to try this out.

IMAAPXTjA-ecr3jhLQQ18A.text: I adore this place. I've been several times, and have never been disappointed.My first time there was with a group of 6 on a Friday night--we had no reservations and the entire lower ground floor was reserved for a party of 40. Rather than shoo us out, the friendly (understandably flustered) wait staff seated us in a cavern-like room behind the curtain, under the stairs. (My friends and I affectionately refer to this room as the lair.)   Because it was such a busy night, the kitchen was a bit slow, but we were kept happy with the well-priced (not so bad) carafes of house red (their old-fashioned pimms is also mixed quite well). The food was (later I found out, always is) amazing--the lamb dishes and goat cheese appetizers are my favorites, and the desserts were wonderful (and good for sharing).   After we were finished, the waitresses (probably exhausted), let us sit for as long as we wanted to finish our wine. I would recommend this place to anyone--for a group, a date, or even by yourself because it's that freaking good.

KGPKDlFJYZDIETlfXMgZ0w.text: Whoa there - 5 stars, are you sure?Fantastic setting - checkGreat service - checkMouth watering food - checkReasonably priced - checkLeft venue with a high alcohol blood level - checkSeriously tasty food, all French themed and beautifully cooked. A little too central for my liking but that's only because I want it in my hood. Bum!

6sDQSJPg1bIl9dG2WgkMXw.text: This place evoked so many feelings in me, some contradictory.Apprehension. One of the first places where i decided to go solely based on yelp reviews (and i had 3 vegetarian friends with me)Elation. The food was so good ... so tasty. I loved the foie gras ... and the steak ... yumm :)Wonder. I am used to French food in London being pretty expensive. It came to be 21 quids per head ... very very reasonable.Disappointment. This is a very veg-unfriendly place. There was only one vegetarian option among the main course ... gnocchi. My friends didn't like it and they ended up having a horrible dinner, made worse by the fact that i enjoyed my share of the food. So i ended up having to pay for all of them :(So this turns out to be one of those restaurants where i would like to come often but i won't be able to since i can't bring my friends along. But maybe someday when i am all alone ...

mkpNhza262zJnyzKPenAmA.text: Sacrebleu! Savoir Faire is more French than a baguette french kissing a croissant over a bottle of Bordeaux.And I'm not talking Walt Disne-fied French. (Let's just say that the singing candelabras named Lumiere and the les poissons loving chefs were absent from the experience.)Humble and unpretentious, Savoir Faire has been one of my favourite London dining experiences to date. Not because of fancy views or exquisite menus, but because these folks are living their dream and doing it authentically -- and that is beyond admirable. Savoir Faire is not a chain nor a franchise, but rather a 10-year old family run restaurant.  It was so family run that when I called for a reservation, I had to spell out the words "E-i-g-h-t P-M" so the French speaking host could decipher my American accent. Each table gets a basket of freshly baked bread, every menu item is made 100% in house, and they source only the best-wines-for the-money. In fact, the entire experience was quite affordable -- a two course meal for £16 seemed like stealing.On that note, I stole the grilled mushroom with melted mozzarella and roasted pepper AND the Nile perch with roasted garlic and lime beurre blanc. Others indulged in grilled mussels, pan fried foie gras, lacquered duck magret, treacle-glazed pork belly, wild boar and mushroom terrine ... it's agonizing typing this out because it makes me want to turn around and go right back. Really, the experience was perfect. Quaint, unpretentious, delicious, affordable -- and to give credit where credit is due: all thanks to Tom E's talk thread suggestion!  ;) God, I love Yelp! Especially when it allows me to find hidden gems like Savoir Faire.

g4DEyoRKHYMNvmiX7uJZHQ.text: Great food, and the set menu prices were really decent. The waitress even helped us find the cheapest combination for everyone to get what they wanted.

_SaR01yr02Gmc3mhohDClQ.text: I'm sad to say that my romance with Yelp has been on the rocks recently. Don't get me wrong, she treats me right- it's me that has been the lazy one not putting the effort into our relationship. She give, give ,gives, telling me where all the best restaurants are and tracking my favourite reviewers. Like an ever faithful lover, she's always there when I walk in through the door at the end of the day, tired and emotional with no energy to type. And what do I do in return? Skim the cream of the crop for reviews before sneaking off to...watch TV! Well I'm a changed woman now. Savoir Faire has made me see the error of my ways. A restaurant this good needs to be Yelped with tender love and respect. Finding places like this is what made me fall for Yelp so hard in the first place and, it made me realise, I know we're meant to be together, through the good times and the bad...So anyway, to the restaurant. Where to start? With the food? The incredible sweet cinnamon glazed duck breast with an oh so tiny cube of dauphinoise? Or the phenomenal (and pungent) mussels floating in garlic butter?Or maybe you'll get a better sense of Savoir Faire if I tell you about the wine. Our fruity Rioja was the hussy of vinos. She went with all of us, snogging us hard before leaving us desperate for more. For the second time in this review- I was in love (so I wear my heart on my sleeve!).If I've left you in any doubt, Savoir Faire is an amazing restaurant. Everything about the place is as French as you could imagine, from the staff to the decor. Stunning Lautrec murals are painted across the walls in the back room and baskets of home made bread arrive at the tables with the minimum of fuss. The prices here are incredible too. Two courses of tasty, tasty French fare cost only £16 and I am in no doubt that it was worth every penny. After this rambling review all that's left for me to say is Yelp, I'm sorry. I'll never take you for granted again.

ILHXtD4xqB5r-BMnti5-tA.text: Exceptional value, and great food.  The Goose Rillettes entree was particularly delicious, but all dishes were prepared thoughtfully and of high quality.  It's a small place so reservations are a must.

SukWoB9GJO3PlbBfhzDGlg.text: Savoir Faire, C'est magnifique!  This cafe deserves high marks. Well-priced, food is anything but typical.  Great wines, unsnobbyatmosphere, lovely private dining with murals of Henri de Toulouse- Lauterac. I love family run business. Which gives you the special feeling of being part of their family. And to sharing their piece of love to you. Entrecote steaks, is known as rib steak. My favorite steak is theirbest Australian rump steak.  Everything is the menu is worth trying. Be adventurous!! Reservations is recommended for large groups.

QMoqV2EkM-ADyxICdnGs2Q.text: After telling as many of my friends as possible about Savoir Faire, I still don't know why most people have never heard if it.It's a small ground floor French restaurant with a dungeon-like cellar perfect for groups. The cellar consists of the entrances to several former smuggling tunnels dug to take moonshine and stuff into Soho from outside the old city limits. These tunnels are mostly blocked now but the entrances make for wondereful private dining alcoves and each has been fitted with a large table and candlelight. If you are thinking of somewhere good to dine with a big group, then think no more - a private tunnel table at Savoir Faire is ideal.Did I mention yet that the walls of some of the alcoves are painted with murals by Toulouse Lautrec?Or how about that George Orwell used to come here to write his weekly Observer column?On top of that location and history stuff, it's also an enjoyable meal. French food in London can run so ridiculously expensive for tiny portions with an astronomical wine list and snotty waiters - not here. The food is well-priced French classics, hearty yet elegant, the wine is carafe-served and affordable and the staff seem to be a decent bunch. It's like they want to break every stereotype for french restaurants.The final bonus of this great find is that it's right close to The End and is a great place to start a big night out with friends.

a1i6nuD24nO0ECLhtksB1w.text: Found on Yelp and were not disappointed.  So close to British Museum that this makes the perfect stop for a lovely and not touristy dinner.  We had made reservations on line that were honored and service was great. We were able to enjoy good wine have a delicious French dinner and make our play on time!  Very reasonable for London.  You will love this charming spot!

8m1FTkJJxOrVIR6fOkUuuA.text: 3.8 maybe?Thought I'd go here for my last meal before departing London, considering all the amazing reviews.  Came with a group of 7, they seated us in a very tiny and adorable underground cove area that was secluded from the rest of the restaurant.Here's the breakdown:Atmosphere: 5The place is adorable, service is great, and when you're there, it almost feels as if you're not in London anymore, but a quaint restaurant off an alley somewhere in a French town.Value: 5The prix-fixed 2-course menu for 16.50 is amazing in terms of the variety that they provide for you for both courses -- appetizers ranging from asparagus salad to gazpacho to steak carpaccio to mussels and goat cheese; mains from braised lamb to duck with red wine sauce/chocolate to beef bourguinon to perch (our party ordered all of these, btw).Food: 3.5For what you pay for, this place is definitely worth it. In terms of the food alone, however, I wasn't all that impressed. The menu sounded promising, but I was actually disappointed with how the food turned out -- not that it was bad, it was just average to good at best -- not quite up there with the consistent 5-star reviews. My steak carpaccio was seared far too much; the sauces for the duck and the lamb tasted the same to me, the duck had too much fat and not enough crisp. Everything else was fine, but not spectacular.Bottom line -- I like it, and it's definitely worth checking out, but doesn't quite go up there with my favorite places to eat in London.

r1H6AlGscZy0-AwdQLvr5Q.text: When I'm in London, I spend a lot of time at the British Museum and I'm voraciously hungry on the conclusion of my visits.  I avoid any other eating establishment on the perimeter of the museum grounds and eagerly make the short walk to Savoir Faire because their delicious fresh food, in an environment that is very cozy and soothing, revives the stomach and the soul.

TD-Ohkj0BD--6NUAvqHVmw.text: On a Sunday afternoon when many french restaurants are getting thin Savoir Faire shined. I found and went here based on a couple very favorable Yelp! reviews and was not disappointed. Wonderful, unpretentious ambiance and a delightful original menu. I had a smoked fish chowder full of flavor to start and a butternut squash risotto that was wonderful. An off the menu tarte tartin closed. R. had soup and then then a very nicely done sea bass. Kids were delighted with omelette du fromage and burger & frites.  The wine menu did present a bit more of a challenge than I would have expected with too many single grape new world wines but we were happy with our french bordeaux, young but a nice light taste that fit our fish and risotto. This could well turn into a sunday afternoon fav, especially at the price.

RSzErFX8PGzWiqLONNWA_w.text: We enjoyed our meal here at 6 pm on a Monday night.  My husband ordered from the pre-theatre/lunch menu and i went for the regular dinner prix fixe. The menu had some interesting and unusual items that would not be found at a chain restaurant.  Our starters were lamb kidneys in mustard sauce and mussels prepared like snails.   I didn't really like the latter more than the usual types of mussel dishes but enjoyed the novel approach.  My husband was happy with his bouillabaisse.  My lamb shanks were very tender.  The tarte tartin was less tasty than others I have had, with a rather soggy bottom crust.  Overall it was a good experience with attentive service and reasonable prices.  I would give it a 3.5 ratting if I could. Maybe it even deserves 4 stars, not sure.

zzXuP4iY7VuNYsh91GYIKw.text: My wife and I went to Savoir Faire on the basis of the 4.5 star Yelp rating. Thinking we were in a cosmopolitan city like London, the rating meant a lot to us in selecting the restaurant.  We were very disappointed.We started with the mussels which were grilled and then served with a pernod butter garlic sauce.  The mussels were the best of the dinner and we rated them a 7 on a 10 point scale.  Things went down hill quickly from there.The second course was the warm goat cheese and fig salad on arugula ("rocket") bed.  It was mediocre, despite our high expectations.  It could have had more arugula which would have added to the experience, and fresher  rather than wilted.The third (main course) was the Entrocote Steak Frites.  We ordered it medium rare.  It was cooked to the right temperature, but the steak was as tough as shoe leather, despite the chef pounding it for a long time before cooking it.  The french fries were okay.For dessert, we had Vanoffee which was a pie with toffee and banana and whipped cream on a graham cracker shell.  It was good but not spectacular.The service was pretty good and we had no complaints about the serve staff.  Finally, the ambiance was just fair.  No table cloths, paper napkins, etc.In summary, Savoir Faire does not deserve more than a 2 star rating.  It is inexpensive, but very average.

PIgYD1oo2VpRukCFFS_bCA.text: Tasty French food at a reasonable price. It was a busy Saturday night, but service was still good.  Was a great find for dinner.

6kC5KPJg4JcwYLBYoBtlCA.text: Cutest little french bistro in central London. Two of us were there for dinner on a Sunday night and it gets really busy so try and make a reservation ahead of time. Dinner comprised of a set menu of two courses with a range of options for the starter and mains. We had the grilled mussels and pan fried foie gras as our appetizers and they were both excellent. For our mains, we had the fillet of sea bass and the braised lamb shank. Although the lamb was good, the sea bass was definitely better - so good! Tried the creme brulee for dessert but I thought it was pretty average. There is also an extensive wine list to choose from. There can be a little bit of a wait for the food to arrive when the restaurant is really busy, but it's not excessively slow by any means. The food is excellent, the atmosphere is cozy, the decor is quirky and fun (there's writing on the ceiling!) and the service is friendly and efficient - definitely worth a visit.

T4J_D9zH7HeUPlMmMXcZUw.text: Good food, good service and reasonably priced. Savoir Faire is a lot more friendly than most French restaurants in London, and feels better for it.

2WGNQErr8m9K-O5L2bDhAg.text: I really like this restaurant,  the food is amazing and the service is friendly.  The prices are reasonable and the decor and atmosphere are both great. The waiter when we were there personally recommended one of the wines, and it was lovely to see some of the diners chatting to each other at different tables,  like it's a place to be socialable and actually talk to other people - something which is very special when you see it in London. I couldn't give this restaurant a higher rating though because of its 2 star hygiene rating by Camden council,  I don't really understand why such an otherwise amazing restaurant would take such a lax attitude to food satety but it isn't a good sign. Hopefully they'll take it on board and try to improve as it's otherwise a wonderful independent restaurant in central London, a welcome alternative to so many identikit chains.

6_XfsLeeydFXcS-BHIA8mA.text: Holy moly... Fantastic food!! So I guess I like French food? If THIS represents French then YES! I started with the baked goat cheese, moved onto the duck, and wow. The flavors are simply astonishing... Although the duck texture was average. Even still.. Epic dish! This is a return over and over places folks! Oh and... Price? It will make you spin your head... The prices are that of a typical chain... Not too high. How? I dunno but I am coming back tomorrow.Ok update (3 minutes after posting!) the texture of the duck is killing me... SO chewy! But... Still 5 star. Why? Flavor... Unique flavor in the whole dish... Everything on the plate is so enriched in unique and DELICIOUS flavor I don't care. Plus it's only a few pieces like that.Sorry 4-star review people who always do 4 starts even when they say it's great! (Why oh why do people do that?)... This is 5 star at its best!Oh... And I hate the French. But you get five stars for food!

9epT8Wd9f9TUNyVVqh29qQ.text: Cest tres bon!!Well this was just a fantastic evening I have to say. The owners ever present in the dining room help to create a warm and welcoming atmosphere. Stepping off a busy London street you are immediately transported to a bistro that could be anywhere in France though I like to imagine myself being somewhere in Provence, wild fields of lavender filling the air with an aroma like to no other....anyway....back to the food!For my starter I went for Goose Rillettes served with Spiced Plums, the rillettes had an excellent texture, neither too fatty or to smooth, there was still a nice consistency to it. I sometimes find rillettes made more like a pate, blitzed to hell and back. The goose with the sweet and spicy plums was a lovely match and very tasty.For my main Herb-crusted Rump of Lamb with Celeriac Puree, Balsamic braised Beetroot and Herb and Tomato Jus. Im a sucker for lamb with a crust and this was done supremely well. Cooked with great attention in a pan then oven roasted to melt in the crust the lamb was still beautifully pink. Celeriac is one of my favourite vegetables and the puree was smooth and well seasoned. Delicious.Washed all of the lovely food down with a bottle of red, reasonably priced and delicious.Finished the night with a French coffee and toddled off into the night very content.

BALKxppEYaXvgRUX5nhXiw.text: I was looking forward to this meal due to the strong reviews...However I was disappointed. To start, I ordered the grilled figs with blue cheese and mint. The figs were neither grilled nor was there mint. In fact the figs were raw and cold. For my main entree, I ordered their honey glazed duck with red wine jus. While the flavors were good, the duck was way over cooked by French standards. If you order the duck you must you must clarify that you want it medium rare.

CvdqNFYwXQiYM5SJrhGv5A.text: The reviews turned out to be spot on. This is some extremely fine french cooking for an affordable price. There are two menus, the lighter menu is 15 pounds and includes an entree and your choice of a dessert or appetizer and then there is the 23 pound dinner menu that includes an appetizer and entree. Both are available at dinner periods and both are delicious (I ordered off the pricier dinner menu while my partner ordered off the 15 pound menu and we were both beyond satisfied). I had a glass of house red (£4) and we both shared a dessert afterwards (£6.50) and the best dinner I've had in London came to a well-spent £50.Service was prompt and friendly and they were even able to fit us in without a reservation, though we came very early. If you plan to eat here after 5:30 I would definitely make a reservation. Off of the cheaper menu I highly recommend the duck legs and off the more expensive menu the lamb shank is delectable.PROs:- Great french cooking- Not dirt cheap, but for what you get it feels like theft- Very close to the British Museum, 5 min from the main entrance. About 10 minutes walk from Holborn station.CONs:- It gets busy quickly, even on weekdays. Make a reservation unless you are willing to take a risk.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

e2-nHoqupjYzfXTmM9j-ng.text: I had lunch here 6 weeks ago after visiting the British Museum and loved it so much I came back today and brought my parents.The fig with ham and goat cheese is absolutely amazing, as are the beef bourguignon and the lamb shanks. The bouillabaisse is amazing if you are looking for a lighter option.Get the house wine by the glass, it's great too.Overall amazing value for money.Only con is food takes a little too much time but 100% worth it!

2T3ScTNvIzwJGvtTrR63BQ.text: Strange decoration but excellent food. All ingredients are self made, including the sauces (hence the name). Good value too given the quality of the dishes. Try it.

CEzqCWokMp_QO9A1HblhGQ.text: I came here with a friend for a bit of a nicer dinner out. We are both students and they advertise this place as an inexpensive gourmet French restaurant...perfect! The service started off as very attentive and we ordered a bottle of house white wine. The waitress quickly brought us a bottle, poured it, and left. Before we knew it we realized she had poured us each a glass of red wine-not what we ordered. This issue would have also been prevented if they showed us the bottle of wine and permitted us an initial taste as every other restaurant does. After much confusion with another waitress who was on her first day and barely spoke English, she was able to help us to amend the issue and she then brought us our white wine. She filled the glasses to the brim-no exaggeration.The starter and main meal was delicious. My friend got the mussels which I would highly recommend. The lentil moussaka was also delicious. Salads were pretty standard, nothing amazing. Overall I would recommend this restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Lentil Moussaka with a side salad.

5KD5uXQfEKD67e-OnthpqA.text: We ate here on our first night  in London. The bistro was a short walk from the hotel. We also had lunch here on our last day in London. Ambiance: small casual restaurant, dining on the street level and a dining room downstairs. Not very lavish but quaint. The location is great for people watching, located on a busy intersection. The narrow staircase and lighting on the way to the loo could use some work.Service: two servers at dinner were very helpful, efficient and welcoming. The servers for lunch were not as pleasant, one hardly said a word but smiled a lot. The other server yelled at tired Japanese tourists who sat on the chairs outside. Not very hospitable.Food: we really enjoyed our dinner here. I ordered the baked mussels which came in an escargot dish and had the traditional butter, herb and garlic butter. Great for dipping the wonderful bread. My wife ordered the steak frites and I had the calf's liver. Both were very good. No dessert. Lunch was not as flavorful. We ordered salad, Caesar and the house salad. Neither were exciting, lettuce was not crispy and the vinaigrettes were not very flavorful. Add the less than enthusiastic servers, I wish we went elsewhere for lunch.

Cyt4LvHMOMUMnuArqcX4kw.text: 3 Stars = "A-OK" and that's how I felt about this place. The food was good (4 stars), the atmosphere and decor makes it more of a homey places. Basically, the two didn't match well together. It almost seems like a great top chef lost his job at a Michelin Star restaurant and went to work at a "normal" restaurant.Whether or not this is a good or bad thing is up to you and your personality. I usually expect the two to match because of the company I'm with, but if you are just a casual dinner looking for great food, this is your place. The food and it's presentation is far beyond the way the restaurant looked and operated.

usBOVOIFw6hjhl-vUOMeDQ.text: It's a casual French having only a course menu for dinner. It's reasonable but tasty and a big portion!! I liked the soup with smoked salmon and cheese and British traditional beef stew.....
