Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Lack of lamb
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Soup of the day (Oyster)

pr3qlmHyUia2HdZzR_q0PA.text: It's rare for me to return to a restaurant on a second visit. But this restaurant is nothing short of divine.I still dream of the mussels cooked with garlic and Pernod and lemon essence. Everything else left me in a dreamy haze!Run, don't walk here!

t0jN-ilIVONgcbb0xpK9-A.text: Beyond love, beyond adoration, I truly venerate this place. When in London, I stop for multiple meals here. That's me in the alcove to the right of the entrance and someday,   I'll probably just take up a fortnight's residence there.From kidneys, to foie gras, to whatever the special is, food has always been amazing and service attentive.  The only sad thing, is I walked by this place for years before dining there. When I think of the  delightful meals that could have been, I could cry, but I'm making up for it now. Mea maxima culpa. Eschew the high street chain and the mediocre and dine like royalty in a relaxing, unfussy bistro.  Last meal? Dine here! Who needs heaven when you've tasted the food of the Gods.

T7fp8oXh2uQ7hLAGC-aKPg.text: This is a gem of a restaurant. We went before the theater and had wonderful food- the mussels were wonderful as well as lamb shank and duck. Very reasonably priced also.

IRdNRpUtzNYStBamN7fuIA.text: I do not regret choosing Savoir Faire for my birthday dinner, even though it was a complete leap of faith as neither of my friends who accompanied me on the special occasion nor myself had been there before. The place is small and a little quaint, and quirky with the, interesting, wallpapers. It seems really underwhelming upon entrance, but the food we had was truly phenomenal especially considering the prices.The two-course prix fixe menu was a great find in an otherwise such an expensive city. I had mackerel as an appetizer followed by sea bass. Both were cooked and seasoned really well. We also had a bottle of tempranillo and finished the meal with crème brûlée and lemon tart. It truly felt like fine dining on a shoestring, and we got the best of both worlds. My friends also raved about everything they ordered (caesar salad, lentil moussaka, etc). I believe we overheard the servers speak French, which only provided a reassuring sign since there's a better chance the chefs are French as well. The service might be a bit lacking at times - or am I just too used to the American standards - but it doesn't detract at all from the overall value of the restaurant.

wnlEdUgXBu0QOhMIAR2cKg.text: There are pictures of naked ladies all around the restaurant, so I do not recommend bringing your adolescent son here for a meal with his school mates.The menu is reasonably priced and the wines are, too. There are two levels and the bathroom is so small that it made me have panic attacks. Not really. I'm a man, I can handle that kind of stuff.But seriously, the sink was so tiny if my hands had a nervous system, they would have panic attacks. Not really. They are a man's hands. Don't get it twisted.

NcPYB7FnDxHHUrq1Cj5m4w.text: Still at table as I write this. Mussels with garlic sauce presented like escargots was perfectly garlicky. Fig appetizer was excellent. Chicken was lovely. Duck breast was spectacular!  Love this place. Oh and the music playing is perfect.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

3iZC5stZ8pqjLJOvUI2pww.text: At first it doesn't look like much, but very soon it surprises in a very positive way. The atmosphere is very nice, the staff is friendly and helpful and the food... The food is one of the most delicious I've had in a long time in a restaurant. The meals might not be cheap but they're not expensive either - and for that taste they're worth every penny!

s0lvnvNMyVq2FxWXiperMw.text: A cozy restaurant with fresh ingredients with a homecooked touch. I actually felt as if I was sitting in a house being served by my friend's family. The food is good, but waiting almost an hour to have it put in front of you was tough. I had a group lunch and we were on a tight schedule so we promptly ordered at noon hoping to be done before 1PM since we had class. We all ordered different things around the table and were served our appetizers while we waited for main courses. As we were sitting there, I could tell we were getting antsy and constantly checking the time because we knew we were running out and we were going to be late. Not really sure why it took nearly an hour for the food to come out, but I think it's something they should work on for people on a time crunch during lunch time.When it comes down to the food, it was nice. Not exactly out of this world amazing, but it was definitely a nice light meal. The service was good since we were the only ones in the restaurant, but my only gripe is the long wait for the food to arrive at the table. Maybe I'll be back, but not when I'm in a hurry.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Bouillabaisse
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Leg of Lamb
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Chicken with Thyme

R-8Xcf9BRpcQYuCFSI9uWQ.text: Early dinner after the British Museum. Wow! In my 8 year old daughters words, "They are so nice, and they make very good food." We had the fried mussels. Like escargot, with mussels, and excellent French bread. For entrees, we had the lamb shank, duck Magritte with chocolate ganache, and bouillabaisse. All were excellent! Dessert was necessary, so we had chocolate mousse and cheesecake, as well as cappuccino. I can heartily recommend everything.

5H0_MNyTXkQm2fXD84Y3gg.text: I had the vegetarian 2 course special. The goat cheese caprese was good. The Aubergine "cannelloni" were amazing. They were strips of eggplant rolled around a mixture of ricotta with olives drizzled with tahini, and surrounded by green beans, potatoes and roasted tomatoes. If someone would cook like that for me, I'd cheerfully become a vegetarian. One of the best things I've ever had. The service was friendly cheerful and the whole experience was great.

3j2fcwbidHkOFkgs4GEl4Q.text: This quaint little French restaurant was one of my favorites that I had visited in London. The food is authentically mouthwatering, not to mention for a great price. The staff was exceptionally nice. The whole evening was elegant, unpretentious, and definitely something I'd like to repeat. Flawless!

g4s3ZVeP56Aa6cCzdcJuOQ.text: This place is indeed an affordable French gourmet restaurant. They have a 24£ 3 course meal deal that is very good value for money! Usually when you choose a set menu you get very limited choices but this place has so much to chose from it was hard to pick just one! As a starter I had the chicken liver which was REALLY yummy. As a main I had the  beef bourguignon which was really tasty. We ended the meal with a chocolate mousse which was good. The service was really good. Our waitress was very friendly and made great recommendations when asked. The place is a bit tight and if you sit downstairs it is windowless. I would definitely go again and highly recommend this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate mousse
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Chicken liver
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

0NcsUnCrsNcJgaSzkmz7XQ.text: STELLAR SERVICE. They were open Xmas day, didn't need a reservation, the food was delicious, the ambiance was "quaint Parisian cafe," and the service was exceptional.

-HTImANSP8P9I3-f2O2cXA.text: This was the best meal my wife & I had in London.  We arrived just after lunch service had ended (after a long day of wandering around the British Museum) and were still able to order off the lunch menu.  We had the restaurant to ourselves for a little while and we felt welcome and very comfortable in the cozy and inviting dining room.My wife had the steak and brie baguette with onions and horseradish mayonnaise and I had the steak frites. Both of our meals were simply amazing. I followed it off with some chocolate mousse which was the best mouse I have had since my last visit to Paris last year.This restaurant should be a must stop for anyone in this part of London.

ErmxZ63CKrakeVRkxYgZ2A.text: Very clean (although small) tables, toilets, and nice service. Had lunch combo for £14+ it actually charges me £16+ maybe for the service fee. The combo comes with a starter+entrée or entrée+dessert, either way you like. I have the soup of the day for starter, which is chicken vegetables soup. It was really good. The soup is neither too salty nor greasy, with lentil, carrot, and some other veggies. I ordered fish soup for entrée and I think it would be better if they can squeeze more lemon juice in it. The carafe and water glasses are not very clean though. But the bread is superb. My boyfriend ordered Lamb kidney for starter and Duck leg for entrée, he said it was flavorless but I think they are okay. This cafe would be good for you if you are looking for some delicate food with light flavor, and also, if you have enough time since the waiting time is a little long than I have expected.

ZFFvtfTH6-b7CL-7MhCKZA.text: This is an amazingly affordable French restaurant with a set menu which include (joy!) a good selection of vegetarian options. The interior is cosy (but there is a downstairs eating area in the basement as well) and slightly 'shabby-chic' (which extends to the cutlery and glassware as well).The main event is the food: the two course menu is £24, but there is a cheaper vegetarian menu as well. Desserts are £5.90. For the price, in this area of London, it represents fabulous value, as the quality is very good, mostly in the classic French style.On two recent visits, service was very good - friendly but unobtrusive, and they made a real effort to seta us when they were busy one evening.I shall be back.

y-AD-sSTnUJG-TtpOWAvZg.text: We went without booking, but the waitress so kindly helped us get a table instead of just turning us away. Through the dinner, service was top notch, and I really appreciated it -- never take it for granted! Food was solid as well. I had pork belly, which was very flavourful and rich together with the purée. My bf ordered foie gras as starter, which was probably one of the best I ever had. Absolutely adored the ambience -- very artsy and cozy at the same time. Great lighting and perfect for dates. Would love to go back soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

-KnBqKIX3gESsDheImbtCw.text: With a quiet and quaint atmosphere, this restaurant provided genuine French cuisine. The Christmas menu provided only a few dinner options and only 3-4 alcoholic drinks to choose from. Of the small amount of choices, the food was savory. The price was on the heavy side of what usually is attributed to this restaurant (due to the holiday limitations). The staff was friendly and made accommodations for canceling an order midway through our meal when one of our diners decided they weren't hungry (no charge).

uoK6ZViBV0jlkLCwdxNF5w.text: Great French food and great prices. The server was very nice and knowledgeable about the food and the atmosphere was romantic. Perfect dinner for our last night in London. The foe grass was fabulous, cooked perfectly, every ingredient on the plate made sense. We had wild mushrooms with fresh goat cheese, pork belly, beef bourgeoning and bread pudding toffee, perfect way to end a perfect meal.I am definitely recommending this restaurant to anyone that visits or lives in London.

HiI0SsqMqKRJx5BH4TmCCA.text: This restaurant is a true gem! Loved the food and service. I highly recommend this place.The steak was delicious as well as the bouillabaisse.  If you are in the area I would definitely try it out!!

Ub812Zvh8b1EV2NOKcP-GA.text: This is the worst restaurant in London. We have the worst experienced, the receptionist lady is very rude and un accommodative, she showed us a table and prepare the table just wiping it with wet clothes and sat the utensils down on the wet table, so dirty We are very shocked by her action. The whole place looks really dirty and unhealthy

E_iGuyO8t2J3Fx4Km5a-1Q.text: Excellent food and very close to British museum. This place serves the best French food in London for the price. Two course meal for about 23, might sound like a lot but the quality is excellent. The goose appetizer and lamb were the meal for me and it was delicious. Service can be very slow especially if you sit downstairs but the food compensated for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Lamb shank
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

DfRzBGaHkdb28Hm9YRIVJA.text: This French gem is flawless. Food deserves a Michelin star for its high quality preparation and presentation. The service is also peerless. Staff is friendly and amicable. What else can be said---We've eaten here twice for dinner and once for lunch in just the last week. I can and would eat here daily if I could. If you enjoy a high standard like I do, this shiny little bauble is for you! Magnifique! London has so many great places to eat, but this place stands out for its quality sure, but the vibe is also great, no pretense, just fine food at great prices. Feels like a local Parisian bistro. Go!

tR8KASK4vYxPcagBCQbfcg.text: So I have to admit...  I'm not really a fan of French food.  It's usually so rich and heavy and that's just not my thing.  When my coworkers and I were on a trip to London and the cuisine agreed upon by the group was French I was not super excited.  But this meal ended up being great!  They have a two course set menu for around 23 pounds.  The various appetizers tried at our table were the grilled fig with goat cheese, the octopus, the mussels, and the fried halloumi - all were excellent and original.  I would give a recommendation, but really that's probably try them all.  The mussels may have been the most unexpected in serving and flavor - they came out of their shells in a special serving dish, and the sauce was incredibly garlicky and delicious.For entrees, our table had the duck, beef bourguignon, lamb shank, and the vegetable plate.  Again, everyone loved theirs.  The sauces were delicious and balanced out the meat perfectly.And after our fantastic meals, we couldn't stop without dessert.  Our table shared creme brulee, chocolate mousse, and tarte tatin.  And again, everything was excellent.  The chocolate mousse was very rich without being too sweet.  The tarte tatin was very different from ones we have had in the US - the apple was a different texture but delicious.  The creme brulee was excellent as well.The restaurant itself was small and very cute.  A great ambiance.  There were paintings all over the wall, which were definitely different than what we would see in the US, but it was a great little European find for us on our trip.

a21-tt2dehgqi560jBjgiQ.text: Hands down--Wow! My husband and I were in London on vacation for 10 days. We were staying in the Covent Garden area and went to Savoir Faire for dinner one evening. Easily the best meal we had in London (yet nowhere near the most expensive). We hit some big name restaurants and none of the cooking was as spot on as Savoir Faire. The preparations were beautiful and delicious. Savoir Faire is a small, unpretentious, neighborhood restaurant. It is casual and comfortable, but the food is the epitome of French style. We had a very affordable bottle of Chateaudeuf-du-pape. I have to admit that I have forgotten after a almost a month away from home what we had for a starter. We both ordered chicken for dinner. It was moist and delicious with a wonderful array of vegetables, perfectly prepared. We shared a dessert. Everything was perfect. This is the restaurant I will be talking about and recommending to anyone I know heading to London. It is small, so make a reservation, but it is a must try.

SbXrcCYFu79AulJ3FQ8E_Q.text: Food was not amazing. Just ok. We were looking for true French cuisine but this was pretty plain.

RhOOLzme_09PO1OvLP66Gg.text: Inaptly named. Nice food, poor service. In a restaurant w few people folks itching to get their bill. Food was tasty, especially chocolate mousse, and good price, just slow and hard to get attention w service

V1qdX_zLd-EnCJ7Qu-n9jA.text: Food was excellent but the chef was clearly overtaxed on a Friday night, leading to delays in food arriving. To make matters worse the owner and his wife, gruff white haired elderly couple, arrived and were served their food immediately, bumping me and other customers back (my entree didn't arrive until an hour after ordering).  Owner then curtly refused to take anything off the bill though his own meals had preempted the paying customers.

XQ1n107ionGTgkY-8eNxTg.text: This was my very first dinner in London, and I was definitely satisfied. A few friends and I came here after seeing how it was so highly reviewed on Yelp, and when we got to the restaurant we were surprised (but I guess happy) at how empty yet small it was. There was probably only one other table occupied, and a total of 7 tables in the room we were seated.The menu contained a lot of options, but I wanted something light so I ordered one of the vegetarian dishes. I can't remember what it's called, but it had mushrooms topped with mashed garbanzo beans/chickpeas and a side of broccoli and carrots. I'll admit that when the food first came out I was a bit skeptical since it's not the prettiest dish, but the first bite destroyed any doubt. The taste and texture of the mushroom paired with that of the garbanzo beans was amazing, and the broccoli/carrots were wonderfully cooked as well. I especially liked how the sauce was light and only used to enhance the taste (rather than drenching the food in sauce, which is kind of common nowadays in a lot of restaurants). After finishing I was well-satisfied and happy.Overall a great place to eat if you like authentic French food! I loved my experience here (food, service, and the super cute decor).

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Awesome wall decor
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian Dish (mushrooms with mashed chickpeas/garbanzo beans, broccoli, carrots)

-VvoRGKALkocnhkuksieQw.text: Came here after a visit to the British Museum and was able to sang a table. The service was excellent and prompt, and I opted for the two course menu. The house wine was also good for the price.The scallops were perfectly cooked and paired well with the apples. The duck really shined - the skin was crispy and the meat was succulent and delicious. I also had the tarte tatin for desert, which was not overly sweet and paired with a very nice custard.The atmosphere was cozy and warm, and the prices were reasonable for the location. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area.

5BeHIGRSzR4yBnhDHW-67g.text: My girlfriend and I came here for a quick dinner before a show. It's puzzling to read all these rave reviews, which almost makes me wonder if we even dined at the same restaurant.I ordered the pre-theatre 2 course dinner with chicken liver pate (starter) and lamb moussaka with salad (main). The pate was good (3.5 stars) but the lamb moussaka was just ok (3 stars). For the price (£15.90), it wasn't bad, but I just don't see why I want to come back here. My girlfriend ordered the special 2 course dinner (£25.90) with traditional beef bourguignon. She was complete underwhelmed by the quality of the food. I'm sure she will give 2 stars or even 1.When it comes to the ambience, some may say intimate and romantic, but I thought it was cramped and grungy. We are not returning here for sure.*****************************If you found something useful in my review, please hit "useful" so that I can improve my reviews. If you love food and traveling, follow me, or better yet, let's become friends on Yelp! Thank you and happy Yelping!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Chicken liver pate, the starter I chose as part of the pre-theatre 2 course menu
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Lamb Moussaka with salad, the main I chose as part of the pre-theatre 2 course menu
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Traditional Beef Bourguignon

NRbLx2sKfW4_zpPtYuicyQ.text: Poor service and bland food. I'm pretty easy to please but neither the food or service could make this a place I would recommend. This is an overpriced tourist trap at the best. The French onion soup was bland. How does a French restaurant serve bland French onion soup?Our fries were brought out 20 minutes after the rest of our food. So many better places to eat than this and at much better prices.

PSlMmxssPD0FAOc-bDW0rQ.text: Came here with a large group for dinner. We all got the two courses set because we were hungry. Sets come with fresh bread with oil (yum!). We also ordered two bottles of wine. Service was slow but polite. The atmosphere was incredibly relaxing and it felt like one could stay at the table all night talking and unwinding. I got the braised lamb with stuffed mushrooms as a first course. The mushrooms were well seasoned and topped with a generous helping of herbs and goat cheese (double yum!). The lamb was cut into thick, juicy slices and resting on a bed of roast potatoes, steamed carrots and green beans, mashed potatoes, and ratatouille. Absolutely fabulous. Everything tasted amazing. The only incident was the small deep fried ball of meat that came on the side of my plate. I thought it looked like some sort of deep fried organ so I didn't eat it... I wonder if it landed on my plate by mistake during serving.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Sauteed stuffed mushrooms with goat cheese and herbs yummm
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Braised lamb w roast potatoes, steamed veg, a bit of mashed potatoes and ratatouille, and some weird deep fried meat ball I didn't eat
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Delightful creme brulee. The sticky toffee pudding was excellent too.

NhUL4GXZAsEiusWJmedBpA.text: We headed here after spending an afternoon at the museum. We were slightly early for our booking, but were seated immediately, while waiting for our friend to arrive.Service was lovely. They only had 2 meal menus, but since we were hungry, they allowed us to order extra starters.The food was excellent. From starters to desserts - pate, lamb kidneys, the sea bass, lamb and duck - each one perfectly cooked. And some of the best French fries that I've eaten in a very long time. They had some excellent wines and the whisky cheesecake was outstanding!Wish I had found this place before my mum and dad visited, would have loved to take them here on one of their many visits to the museum.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Garlic mussels
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

Ndf68XdG5_NZJFoTFYoKhw.text: This was a delightful and cozy spot! We we thrilled to find it! We love French food and this place hit the nail on the head. The food is incredibly reasonable especially considering how amazing it all tastes! The staff was wonderful - they answered our questions happily and were very attentive. They even offered some suggestions of things to go on our trip to Paris. My husband and I shared some wine, French of course, and were pleased! For appetizers we had the goose rillete and  baked goat cheese - it was an amazing start to our meal. For dinner my husband had roast duck, which was perfectly cooked, and I had seared sea bass which was delicious! The skin had a crispness to it without drying out the fish. We ended the meal with cheesecake which honestly, was the best we've had! The texture was almost whipped it was so smooth and light.  Without a doubt I would recommend this restaurant. There is nothing about the experience that I could give lower than 5 stars to. If you ever find yourself in London, on or near Bloomsbury way, stop in for a bite. You won't regret it!

MzyRmVDkq6M1kt1wp2Pd7A.text: What a treat! We ducked in out of the rain and found a table - our good luck. The service, the food (bouillabaisse x 2, bread, salad, wine, coffees), and the setting were wonderful, it's a very charming place.    Other choices include a veg prix fixe menu and assorted food for carnivores. Good value, a great meal.

HtflDigw8BnWOOBFukW0Ow.text: Fabulous little bistro we happened to find while getting away from the normal tourist trap establishments.  Owners were working hard as staff was either on holiday or out ill.  They did a terrific job and we loved our delicious meal and wine.  Everything was fresh and made to order.  Prices were extremely reasonable.

0E1XwK5TpRLjfGWgiawj8w.text: I travel to London fairly often for work so I am usually out dining alone. The food was fantastic and the service was pretty good. I had two lovely ladies waiting on me, however, I asked the less experienced waitress for a wine recommendation and she had no idea what to say, so I ended up with a bottle of house wine, which was perfectly fine, but I would have loved a recommendation on a proper french wine as I'm always looking to broaden my palate and learn more about wine in general.Still, a wonderful experience overall, highly recommend it!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

NwR1TFrn7IbAvx9oaWyHag.text: This tiny French cafe was a great choice during our stay in London. We were craving something fresh and yet still delicious. They have a pre-fix lunch menu with a salad and a meat option. The salad the day we visited was a roasted pear salad, it look so good but I wasn't hungry enough for multiple courses. I did end up with a salad though and so did another guest in my party. I ordered a butternut squash and goat cheese salad and it was perfectly dressed and a larger serving- I would recommend! The other salad ordered was a warm chicken and avocado salad- which was also very tasty and a large portion. We also had a steak and Brie sandwich on a fresh baguette- it was perfection. The bread was so fresh and soft yet the outside perfectly crispy. Everything we ordered was great and I would highly recommend this spot! The upstairs area is smaller and doesn't have air conditioning, which is fine normally but we were visiting on an 80 degree day- so just keep that in mind! The downstairs area is larger and cooler, but lacks the charm of the upstairs area, however this would be better for larger parties! Go here!

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

W0VELDvoxKzPFlO6CSuS_A.text: Maybe I was just unlucky, ordering the wrong dish... I couldn't eat more than half - it tasted weird. The bread had little gnats flying on it too and was too hard, like it'd been cut up hours before. I like the ambience of the place though, and the waitress, though she seemed stressed. I hope she gets a vacation or something good soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. The ceiling
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom

0DFiEeKXnajV8mHJSuppMA.text: We really enjoyed Savoir Faire.  Although our children are not fond of French food, the menu had enough options to please everyone.  The waitresses were very helpful and friendly. We found the food to be good, and the atmosphere pleasant.

nyRf7juYXKL6NOPTHEIDLQ.text: My friend and I had a late lunch here around 2:30 pm on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. We came from the British Museum, which was just a short walk away. It was fairly empty at the time, so we had our pick of indoor and outdoor seating; we picked a small table inside, right by a window, and got a nice view of the street and nearby buildings. There was also plenty of seating, as well as toilets, downstairs, although no one was sitting downstairs because it was so sunny outside (the downstairs area was quite dark but would probably be cozy in the evenings). We were greeted promptly by our server.Both of us ordered the butternut squash and goat cheese salad (my friend is a vegetarian). The food came out pretty quickly. I was pleased with how generous they were with the toppings; they had completely covered the greens with goat cheese, sliced nuts, and squash. The salad came with dressing on, but I'm sure you could ask for it on the side. It was really tasty; there might actually have been too much cheese, but as goat cheese is my favorite, I was pretty happy with it. The salads came with 1 basket of bread that we split; we wound up ordering more, since there wasn't that much in the 1st basket. The bread was accompanied by some seasoned olive oil, which also had sesame seeds in; it was pretty addicting for me as a bread lover. However, as it was a French restaurant, I was expecting the bread to be better; it was good, but I wasn't as blown away as I have been at some other French/Italian/Spanish restaurants.For dessert we split (well, I had 75% of it) a pear tarte tatin (when asked, the server informed us the dessert special of the day was mango sorbet). The tarte was a good size and really tasty; it was served warm. If my friend had been hungrier, I would've wanted to order 2 desserts, as the tarte wasn't really big enough to split equally between 2 people (although I have a big appetite so your mileage may vary).The restaurant had a great atmosphere and a nice view of the street. We were allowed to take our time and weren't bothered much by anyone throughout our leisurely meal. The facilities and tables were clean. The ceiling was decorated with some humorous sayings, so look up if you visit. Our meal came out to be about £15/person, including 1 glass of wine, 1 dessert, and an extra basket of bread. I really enjoyed my lunch here and would happily return if I'm ever in the area again.

photos.caption: Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Pear tarte tatin
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Ceiling on main floor
Photo of Savoir Faire - London, United Kingdom. Seating on main floor

_KSiWyO6inoLF4x6Qbf5jw.text: A cute spot to grab good food and a drink or two.I enjoyed the Aperol spritz. It wasn't too bitter and it was refreshing. The bread you get with dinner is nice and soft. It's served with oil for dipping.For dinner I ordered a mixed greens salad and the vegetarian tagine. The mixed greens (smallish) included frilly greens, a few slices of tomato and a creamy dressing. It was alright. The tagine was pretty good though. It included cooked carrots and apricots in a flavorful sauce with mint over couscous. I just wish there were a few more different veggies in there. My sister ordered the large vegetarian butternut squash and goat cheese green salad. It was super flavorful and the portion was generous. She also ordered the fries (chips), which were a little thinner than I normally like but not bad. I do like how there are several vegetarian options.Our waitress was pleasant and helpful. The decor is fun and nice. I enjoyed the quotes written on the ceiling.If I come back to London I would visit Savoir Faire again.

Rc9DfVCVobV-XtzqcTdeHg.text: Lovely lunch where everyone left happy and satisfied with their meal.  Excellent service.

YheYSzbP9PTPrtzawvuh5w.text: Great French food. Good value and price for London. I love when you can get your own carafe of wine. I had the fish special and my husband had the lamb. Both were delicious. Highly recommend.

wKwe-yHxAU5pJhe3_xw3tw.text: SO. GOOD. I've been for lunch a couple of times and simply cannot fault this place. The service is exceptional and they are even accommodating when I have a baby with me. The food can take a while to come out but when it's as good as it is here, I can't complain. The lunch deal is a steal. The staff are incredible. Thank you.

qxaesyGKQ3HnOm6-qLdI1w.text: Loved it! Great food, reasonable prices, great service. Very small place and not a chain. Would definitely recommend!

Ra6n_FuwqJT23OXDpsw2_Q.text: After a day at the British Museum we found this location via the other great reviews on Yelp, and it didn't  disappoint.

rfBJu-iacluZwUFdH3NETQ.text: Visiting London for the first time, a friend and I tried this restaurant. It was in close walking distance to the London National Museum. The food was food and they have a two course special for early dinner. However, if you do not have a reservation you are not allowed to sit on the ground floor but are quickly whisked away to the basement to dine. The food came out quickly, however the waitress disappeared for a long time when we were dining and it took about 30 minutes longer to finally get our check.

rQPWt6kmtTl032wXkDXWOQ.text: If you're looking for lovely gourmet French cuisine in a romantic little restaurant oozing with character, look no further than this surprisingly affordable central London gem.  I've been there three times now - it's a favourite romantic dinner date for my boyfriend and me - and will go there many more times, whenever I can come up with a good excuse!  One of the things I love the most is that even though the food is excellent and French, the atmosphere manages to be romantic without being pretentious.  The waiters keep an eye on you without making you feel like an uncultured heathen.  My biggest problem with it is there are always more things on the menu that I want than I can possibly consume!

0BSj57aW0_zFYi3dnorQ-A.text: Excellent as always. My 15 year old son ordered a hamburger. Even it was excellent.

fGGXMSU6W1hqCypJ3iNJ9g.text: Great food, nice service, small bistro and very reasonably priced. Not a fast place to eat, but have a glass of wine while you wait. The pan fried Foie Gras was yummy.

dVvCIAKkH8ayncRkXT__8A.text: Great food! Went there with family and we all enjoyed our food. Waitress was nice enough to give us the special even though time was up. It is quite refreshing to eat European portion size. It is a few blocks away from touristic area, so that is another plus.

kSt7l9EFZcTSqMNHqBah0w.text: Cozy French place with good service and tasty food.

FZr_AKzrlcuOF1SnrhwcqQ.text: Very good place with authentic French cuisine! Highly recommended *****

ZKkvACgYemCIgMMH-BG7hA.text: Great value!  Offers a 2-course set menu for a little over £20 with lots of variety (starters and mains). I opted out on the starter this time, but the mains on their own are a good deal as well. Had the slow roasted pork belly which was perfectly crispy, meaty and fatty all at the same time, although perhaps a bit too saucy. For desert, split the banoffee pie with a friend - more banana than toffee, but the crust was crumbly and it was a nice way to top off the meal!

JUFzZ9F2JbQ_Wd9IpNYKZQ.text: Excellent little unassuming French place. Got the courgette and aubergine stuffed with small prawns... which was taste perfection. Then I got the pork belly, which was too much food and also the glaze was too sweet. The service was excellent. Good value as well.

osRJ3ZixviMt67Uw3FYdTA.text: We had the garlic mussels, goat cheese salad, broccoli soup as starters and they were all good especially the garlic mussels! We then had the lamb shank, fish of the day and sea bass and again they were all delicious. I recommend this place for a good and reasonably priced meal.

in9nEs_cEkZWw1yydXr6yg.text: You know, sometimes where you really look forward to try a place, it really lets you down.  This is what happened with Savoir Faire.I am not sure whether it was the terrible weather or the fact I just came back from Paris, but I kinda expected bistro food at Parisienne prices and Parisienne quality.  That, unfortunately, Savoir Faire was not.  The price atmosphere and level of service was about right, but the food was a little off the mark.It was also very slow, and who wants to wait ages for their food on what was perhaps the first real wintery evening of 2009?

SypSBKczDLpUHZdTtvTQ-Q.text: What with all the five-star reviews of Savoir Faire here on Yelp, I was expecting to be served up a loin of unicorn with a side of fairy-dusted mash.But it was not to be.  The food I received was thoroughly average.  The wine was potent and flowing, though, and the amount of time between courses was incredibly drawn out (and filled with more wine drinking).  So I wasn't entirely upset by the mediocrity of the meal at the time.  My fig and cheese starter was nothing special, and my fish main was overseasoned but cooked well.  I was too intoxicated by the time my dessert arrived to remember much about it.In the end, I left with the impression that the courses were actually quite small for the price coupled with the inattentive execution of the dishes.  And I was kind of hungry.

QUvcywLY6YqWPNRxbq5Sfg.text: What a happy coincidence we found this great place for lunch! Welcoming and warm, food was excellent, served quickly and attentively. Beef Daube and duck leg with lentils; expertly cooked and served very hot. Well done!

7Tw59ZZQeOLBVmceRbMUFg.text: Not far from the hotel I was staying in.  I passed this place a number of times as I wandered around London.  It was not until these glowing reviews on Yelp! that I decided to give it a try.I had their 2 course special (a steal at ~17 pounds).  I started with their smoked salmon and asparagus starter.  It was beautifully presented and delicious.  I followed it with their rib-eye with Bearnaise.  It came with Potatoes au gratin (which I normally do not like but these were good) and some steamed veggies.I washed it down with a half liter of their house red wine (also delish).  All in all a very good meal.  One of the best I have had in London.

Akwd5HgRepi2U92MQqjYZQ.text: It is a tad unfair to review a French restaurant after spending a week driving around the south of France in a convertible gorging oneself on French food and wine, but that's the situation I find myself in.  One must persevere in such conditions, although I suspect the juxtaposition of eating in the south of France with eating in the middle of the tourist district of London is why my star rating is lower than others'.Savoir Faire is reasonably priced by London standards; 2 entrees, 2 mains, 1 dessert, and a carafe of house red cost under 50 quid.  I was underwhelmed by the food, however.  I had the beef carpaccio and the lamb shanks, and while both were fine, they weren't exactly screaming with flavor.  My co-eater had a tarte tatin for desert which was the least genuine tarte tatin I have ever seen in my life:  it looked like someone had taken apple sauce and placed it on top of pastry, and then covered the whole lot in custard.  Maybe it was designed for 80 year olds who had lost their teeth and couldn't chew?There are some pluses though.  The cafe has a nice family feel and it was packed when I went which is always a good thing.  Also the waitresses actually spoke French which meant I could flirt with them in the language of love.  Normally waitresses in London speak Polish which I don't speak and is also the language of sausages, not love.Overall not bad and if you were going to the theatre and needed a quick dinner beforehand you wouldn't be disappointed.  I don't think I'd take a date here.

rWgPCqRltptEAoDEkfgcSg.text: Excellent casual French restaurant!  I had the mussels for first course... out of this world!  Then moved to the sea bass entree... very good.  Service was friendly and more proactive than many places in London.  Atmosphere is intimate, yet the floor to ceiling windows around the entire front makes it feel like you are sitting on the street in this busy part of London.

bSTF8lNRpMxAndoKUxRpIw.text: Yelp, you are my new best friend.  This place is so unbelievably well-priced given its location and the quality of food they serve.  Actually, it's unbelievably well-priced even if it wasn't right in Central London.  There's really not much to say other than that Savoir Faire serves tasty, authentic French food without the fouf and the miserable service.My husband and I each had a delicious starter and a main, and we were so pleased with our two-course dinner that we added dessert.  We asked our (very friendly) server for suggestions, and were thrilled with her recommendations: a delicious mango and basil sorbet, and the bannoffee pie, complete with a crumbly digestive biscuit crust.  Heaven on a plate.We will be back.  We will be bringing our friends back.  But please, don't tell too many other people about Savoir Faire, because I want to be able to get a table next time I am craving their lamb shank.

J-Jr3wr_6oZC2XmWk50a7A.text: Well Savoir Faire...you were a bit of a letdown. Not in a "Oh my gosh, I am going to see that Blair Witch Project film, it looks great!" way. More like "The last Family Guy season wasn't as funny as the others, was it?" The food was pretty good, but not up to what I had heard it could be. Although tasty enough, steaks were stringy and fatty. That lost a star from the review right there! I also felt that starters were lacking in portion size. Overall though, I did really enjoy myself, but that was probably due to the stellar company I was in! The ambience was pretty good in the restaurant, but décor was a little rough in places. Service was pretty slow and inattentive, but to be fair, this was possibly because we were tucked out of the way in the basement, like a pack of grouchy live-in mother-in-laws. All in all, I had a wonderful night, but that standard of Savoir Faire is more comparable to some of the 'Red Café' establishments around town, as opposed to being a newly discovered gem for me.

2NsLmxWp8MVihljxgFZQhQ.text: The food was DELICIOUS!!!! really really tasty.between the three of us we had the fried goatcheese with stewed apples, the pumpkin soup (which was spicy and just perfect for the cool weather), the gnochi with sundried tomatoes and melted cheese, and a pumpkin/goat cheese salad where there were very hefty helpings of goat cheese. The ceasar salad was a staple and the stewed beef with mashed potatoes was perfectly savory. i LOVED!!!we got one bottle of wine for about 17 quid, and entire dinner cost about 65 quid (tip included) so really affordable and delivers great taste for the cash.The lowdown- there are two floors for dining: ground level and lower level. the restaurant is situated on a corner, so on the ground level you can do good people watching and have access to the bar. Lower level is cozy, dare I say romantic and the walls are adorned with oil murals of tasteful nudity and big mirrors here and there. - the bathrooms are cavernous and are truly tiny, but cute. To enter the women's restrooms there are literally 3 different doors. The only time i felt claustrophobic was in there.- there is NO music in the background. I didn't like that, and that is part of the reason why i took the 5th star out .- the crowd is diverse in terms of age, so don't expect to go there and find collegiates in mini skirts, but rather groups of people wanting to have a laid back conversation and a good time without having any use for background encouragement. - I suggest you go with your partner for a quiet night out, or with parents. not the place to go for loud fun.FOOD delicious!!! i will go back : ))

LNcMhhn95VrA9BWXdDel7A.text: Where do I even begin to describe this fantastic meal? Maybe it was the fact that we had a 2 course meal for only £16.90? Maybe it was the fact that they had a half carafe of the house wine for £8.00?Maybe it was because the food was so god damn tasty!?!!!?This place is adorable, it seems small at first, but there is a whole other floor in the basement. It's the type of place where you could sit with a glass of wine outside with a good book, and just stay there all day. Or it's a place where you can enjoy a fabulously good meal.Joe and I opted for the 2 course meal. I went with a goat cheese appetizer that was absolutely fantastic! For my meal I went with the pork belly plate and holy crap, it was some of the best stuff I have ever had in my life. With some mashed potatoes and apple sauce compote, my mouth is watering just thinking about that fantastic meal. Sopped it up with some soft french bread, this meal was definitely a highlight of the whole trip.For dessert Joe and I shared the lemon tart. Again, just awesome. Perfect mesh of sour and sweet, with a little bit of crunch from the crust.This meal was an absolute STEAL, with the amount of food we got and the overall tastiness, when I'm back in London I'm coming back here, and so should you.

xkE55TBYkdnwezl5tCOVgA.text: Beautiful.It's difficult to go back to eating regular, everyday food after dining here. Perhaps my meal was laced with crack and I need another hit. Seriously, I could develop a habit off their mussel starter, and I don't even like seafood that much, but it was so perfectly flavored. Dip the bread into the remaining pesto from the mussels and I guarantee there's nothing better. Ambiance was lovely as well, I enjoyed the quotes written on the ceiling; they could be great conversation starters on a first date.

-bGbIclWBu9h0p0BM_imJg.text: Cute bistro on New Oxford Street with a great value dinner menu (just under £20 for two courses, £15.50 for an entrecote steak, frites and sald).  The interior is pretty quirky and it definitely exudes that family-run feeling that few places in London possess these days.I went for the entrecote option (rare) - I thought it was ok, although noticeably tough.  The flavour was decent though, and the chips were good.  However, whilst eating, I just couldn't help but think of Le Mercury in Angel which has a similar MO and is simply fantastic (and cheaper).  However, I will return here at some point and try some of the other dishes on the menu as I'm aware that the entrecote item may not be treated with the same respect as the other dishes.  Update forthcoming...

O2YjvPcg2vbo6RWq5EN4eg.text: Just outside the much more expensive theatre district, this family-run little eaterie is a delight. My wife and I come here quite frequently for special occasions. The service is friendly but unobtrusive; the food is simply gorgeous (not too much and not too little--so you can just about squeeze in three courses); the house red (available in 4 carafe sizes) is eminently quaffable; and the proprietor, an ex-airline pilot, is friendly and attentive. It is the perfect place to sit and eat and talk as you watch the traffic go by on a rainy evening.The mussels are always worth having; last time we tried something different though, and the asparagus starter was amazing. The steak entrecôte is great.

zyoDl592QuYR8l5LiyEUwQ.text: We visited Savoir Faire recently, while staying in London and it was a wonderful experience. The prices are quite reasonable, whether you order from the pre-theatre or la carte menu. We started with salads and tomato soup, and continued with sirloin steak and salmon.  Everything was perfectly prepared, nicely presented. Dessert was chocolate mousse, and the lightest cheesecake I have ever tasted! Even the coffee was perfect. For us, it was a great way to cap off a vacation.

olZgFhodIHgDcehsq0NrVw.text: Amazing food. Amazing service. I made a reservation for here for my birthday with several guests and they were incredibly accommodating to my unknown exact number of guests and need to pre-order so we could get in & out in 1 hr to make at 7:30 show. They also had great wine recommendations and delicious, interesting food.

rGEJ6UpZ6gd5zE7H6MoJwg.text: We were at British museum and we were looking for a place to eat. We notice there was Pret A Manger everywhere but we wanted something unique in London. Luckily yelpers recommend this place La Bistro Savoir Faire because it turned out to be a hidden gem. The curb appeal definitely does not represent the food they serve. To be honest I probably wouldn't eat at this restaurant without the yelp reviews. Their menu is very simple. The guys had the delicious burger with fries which was huge and cooked just right. The girls had lasagna that came with the best seafood soup. If only I had the recipe! I was told London doesn't have good food but Savoir Faire was delicious.

1qYCe5oKrsVIjonTfIuafQ.text: Euh, zis is simply my canteen when I am in London. As good as home. Ok nearly as good as home (in case my wife reads this), always better than if it's me cooking at home. You can't go wrong with the Boeuf Bourguignon or the Lamb Shank. Zey've added a fig appetiser which is worth trying. Every dish is tastefully executed and presented. Deserts not quite as good but if in addition zey had a patisserie chef zey'd have to raise ze price, so happy to keep it as it is. Done my best to make it clear zis review is coming from a Frenchman...

zyMdsnaqCJyeag4ZHnnlvQ.text: Had a really nice dinner there.The service was very friendly and attentive. My only gripe is that the French style of steak is thin and slightly tough compared with the meat in the US. But the sauce it was served with tasted great.

Y2OTjWtHHUlf025IS87Zww.text: Had dessert here twice while visiting London. Best lemon tart!

zmBZc_h0iM6KeexOvhqEuA.text: So we were at the British Museum and looked at Yelp for something close and this place had 4 stars with 90 reviews so we went and boy are we glad we did.  The foie gras was top notch and for dinner the beef borgunone (spell check does not work) was perfect with the fat rendered just right.  The duck was probably great for a non duck conniseure, but it is one of my favorite dishes so i judge harshly if not exactly right.  Overall the writing on the ceiling is entertaining and the atmosphere is laid back and comfortable, the staff were very polite and as you can see our experience is rated 5 stars.I definitely suggest trying this place, if we are in the area and in the mood for French we will be back, most likely the next time we are at the museum.

05l_PKcnKqFo6_ODGAlN3A.text: Perhaps one of the worst things about Yelp is the expectations. I was expecting a lot out of this place from all the reviews, so I brought my sister here. I can't seem to remember what she ordered, but I had the escargot and a lamb dish. Both were decent, but were really not that great. The lamb was too chewy and the escargot was also lacking some hit-the-spot Frenchy goodness. Nonetheless, it is nicely located in central London and has a nice restaurant setting. I guess you could give it a try if you're itchin' for French food within the area, but personally, I wouldn't itch to go back here again.I also might want to add how funny it was when my (also American) sister asked for a glass of iced tea. The response she received was a facial expression which read "what the hell? ICED tea?!," which obviously came from the English waitress who couldn't understand why on earth one would want their tea ICE COLD. The lack of frigidity to my drinks was definitely something I had to get used to whilst living in London :)

5MMEZE8DqNZ4RemlT9ZCag.text: We went there on the very strong recommendation from our hotel as "the place to go" before heading off to the theater. How right they were.First, the food. It was superbly prepared using obviously fresh ingrediants. Presentation was very nicely done. This is not some big chain establishment with a million things on the menu but a small, family run place that has a selection that is both authentic and just plain delicious. As mentioned, the restaurant is not some huge chain so reservations are in order. We had a small table with a setting that my wife and I would call romantic. This is the kind of place you go if you want an authentic bistro experience. We might not have gone in had we not known about it from the hotel but there is a reason they have a steady stream of regulars.As for the people, our service was top notch and very attentive. Max, the owner, spent time chatting with us. Leaving aside that he is fascinating in his own right, that he visited with us is and wanted to make sure they were meeting our expectations, which they far exceeded, is a reflection of how we found everyone there to be. Our server was especially helpful for our dinner selections and she was very attentive during the evening.I think it simple to sum up our experience. If you want a large chain menu and food, don't go here. If you want superb food with obviously hand picked fresh ingredients and expertly prepared dishes, don't go anywhere else. Max is terrific, the staff is terrific and our total experience was simply perfect. This unmistakably is a gem.

6QUxfOzvSzZ2KoOUO83EPA.text: Wonderful!  This place is pretty ideal for a romantic dinner for two.  The food is always top-notch while the prices aren't crazy.  The service can be a bit smug occasion but if you feel like a nice long dinner with lots of wine then this is a great place to go.

dNHAu8VgzvE92mplaWomfg.text: We ate a lovely meal here on a Sunday evening. The food was delicious and original. The service, contrary to some other reviews, was prompt. I suspect that we were served by one of the owners, who was charming. In London, at this price, a gem.

5mNaBGqFMkAogYJSELrJ8g.text: Hmm, maybe I ordered the wrong thing. The chicken, Pimms, and the staff were fine, maybe I was a little too American or something. The upstairs was very pleasant, and the downstairs looked like a cool place to hang out if you had a large group. Had some Pernod because it felt like the right thing to do. Will def go back but not really in a hurry. Booking via the OpenTable widget above was lovely.

sHzXtXfmwFpj2fmd9e0L1Q.text: Savoir Fair is a good place to eat if you are near the British Museum.  The atmosphere is OK but dated with red plastic tablecloths and stark un-curtained windows.  The food is good and the prices are very reasonable for London.  A nice wine list but the house wine by the glass or carafe was very drinkable.  A choice of a two or three course meal was made easy for me.  Good starters, solid entree and some great desserts.  They had the best (strongest) coffee I had in London.at a restaurant.  I would go back again

LU5nA8yWEw3hYqEBjjRCpg.text: There's an honesty about this French restaurant that is instantly noticed upon entering the tightly packed dining space. You'll be warmly welcomed, but without the sickly sweet cloying of some restaurants. Service is matter of fact and polite by staff who are obviously comfortable within the relaxed atmosphere. I can only speak for one dish on the menu, a dish that shall not be forgotten any time soon, the beef bourguignon. Truely a comforting experience, Heartily recommended.

3ImcudeV9oQtL1-cn3YU5A.text: Dessert is great, meals are cheaper in lunch time.

mLYG6Br_lma0JYgHLnkEvA.text: Unbelievably delicious appetizer and entree (I had duck as an entree), but the lime dessert pie was not good at all. Disregarding the dessert, the restaurant is lovely, service is amazing and multilingual, and food is delicious!

Khgf5BWSr1uUdagBUfFfxw.text: Check your bill carefully, and count your change!   Came on at 17:30, had a nice meal, and obviously had to get going for a show, I had my cash out.  Gave us a bill that was 11£ to much, over charge was on a glass of wine.   Could have been a simple error but three servers were hunched over the area where my bill was being prepared.  There were only three tables of diners in the place.

2vkCTeEJsBEkWRPq6hlJDw.text: A sweet little French bistro in the heart of London offering a la carte and 2-course dinners. The foie gras was great, the duck succulent, and for dessert, sticky toffee pudding (not so French, but that's the beauty of being in London). Everything was reasonably priced, especially the house wine. My only complaint is that the pudding was a little dry.
